text:
Tory minister dismisses £3.7bn disability cuts as 'tweaks' aimed at 'people taking pills for anxiety' George Freeman, who heads up the Number 10 Policy Unit, said cuts which will affect 150,000 people were 'tweaks'   Share   Comments By Mikey Smith Dan Bloom 14:38, 26 FEB 2017 Updated 14:49, 26 FEB 2017 News Video Loading Video Unavailable Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Watch this video again Video will play in  Controversial comments from Tory members on disability benefits Share this video Watch Next   Share   Comments Get politics   A Tory minister dismissed cruel cuts to disability benefits sneaked through by the government on Friday as “tweaks”, aimed at “people who take pills at home who suffer from anxiety.”
Shadow chancellor John McDonnell branded the Tories the ‘nasty party’ after it emerged they had quietly rewritten the law to deny Personal Independence Payments to 150,000 vulnerable people.
Two tribunals had ruled the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) should expand the reach of Personal Independence Payment (PIP) - which helps disabled people fund their living costs.
Yet the DWP warned that would cost £3.7bn extra by 2022 - so unveiled emergency legislation to stop the change happening.
George Freeman, who has been appointed Minister for Life Sciences (Photo: getty) Read More Tory ministers have rewritten the law to deny increased disability benefit payments to more than 150,000 people This morning, Tory Chairman Patrick McLoughlin insisted the government was “very generous” in the amount of support given to disabled people.
(Photo: PA) Speaking to the BBC’s John Pienaar, John McDonnell said: “I could not believe that the government sneak out on by-election day an announcement that they’re going to cut £3.6bn from disability benefits.
The Tories are trying to say they’re no longer the nasty party. They are the nasty party.”
He said Labour would demand Chancellor Philip Hammond reverses the decision ahead of the Budget on March 6th. 
But George Freeman, who leads the Tory policy committee, said: “The truth on the disability budget is that we spend £50bn a year on disability benefits and what we’re trying to do is make sure we’re getting them to the right people who are most in need.
Read More Tory cuts are seizing 800 vital Motability cars a WEEK from disabled people “He didn’t mention these tweaks are actually to do with rolling back some bizarre decisions through the tribunals that now mean benefits are given to people who take pills at home, who suffer from anxiety. We want to get the money to the really disabled people who need it.”
“Anxiety is a very serious mental health condition and actually can stop people from working.”
He said: “I totally understand anxiety, and so does the Prime Minister. We set out in the mental health strategy how seriously we take it.”
Freeman later tweeted that he had suffered from anxiety as a child, insisting he didn’t “need any lectures on the damage anxiety does.”
There are two types of PIP - the "daily living" element and the "mobility" element.
Disabled people are assessed for each type by totting up their circumstances under a 'points' system, where 8 points get a basic rate and 12 points an enhanced rate.
(Photo: Getty) The first tribunal said more points should be available in the "mobility" element for people who suffer "overwhelming psychological distress" when travelling alone.
That would have handed new money to 143,000 people who previously received nothing for the mobility element of PIP.
Half of them would have received the enhanced rate of £57.45 a week, and the other half the standard rate of £21.80 a week, the DWP said.
Another 21,000 people would have moved from the standard to the enhanced rate, giving them an extra £35.65 a week.
The second tribunal recommended more points in the "daily living" element for people who need help to take medication and monitor a health condition. This would have affected just over 1,000 people, a DWP impact assessment said.
We’re going back to Victorian times, where disabled people were hidden away: My Wigan Pier story 
The DWP said together, making these changes would have cost taxpayers £560m in 2017/18, £650m in 2018/19, £760m in 2019/20, £830m in 2020/21, and £910m in 2021/22.
Ms Mordaunt told MPs in a written statement: "If not urgently addressed, the operational complexities could undermine the consistency of assessments, leading to confusion for all those using the legislation, including claimants, assessors, and the courts.
"It is because of the urgency caused by these challenges, and the implications on public expenditure, that proposals for these amendments have not been referred to the Social Security Advisory Committee before making the regulations."
